sections.title: Estimating Retirement Expenses
sections.content: Start by tracking your current expenses and categorizing them as essential (housing, food, healthcare) vs. discretionary (travel, entertainment). Many retirees find their expenses are 70-90% of their pre-retirement income. Consider increased healthcare costs and reduced commuting/transportation expenses in retirement.

points.title: Essential Expenses
points.description: Housing, food, utilities, insurance, and healthcare - these typically continue or increase in retirement.

points.title: Discretionary Expenses
points.description: Travel, hobbies, dining out - these may decrease as you have more time but potentially less income.

points.title: One-Time Expenses
points.description: Home modifications, vehicle purchases, or major travel - plan for these separately.

sections.title: The 4% Rule
sections.content: The 4% rule suggests you can safely withdraw 4% of your portfolio in the first year of retirement, then adjust for inflation annually. This assumes a 30-year retirement and provides a 95% success rate historically.

sections.title: Calculating Your Number
sections.content: Use retirement calculators that factor in your current age, desired retirement age, current savings, expected Social Security, and investment returns. A common rule of thumb is to save 10-15% of your income annually. Adjust based on your specific situation and risk tolerance.

sections.title: Calculate Your Retirement Needs
steps: Estimate your annual retirement expenses (70-90% of current income)
Use the 4% rule to determine your required portfolio size
Factor in Social Security benefits and other income sources
Create a savings plan to reach your target by your desired retirement age

sections.title: Plan for Healthcare Costs
sections.content: Healthcare is often the biggest expense in retirement. Consider long-term care insurance and factor in potential nursing home costs when calculating your retirement needs.
